start.title:
LiDAR & Lines

Uncovering Maya Mathematics
start.description: Deep in the Yucatán jungle, ancient cities have remained hidden for centuries beneath the dense canopy. Using advanced LiDAR technology and coordinate geometry, you'll join archaeologists to reveal the mathematical genius of Maya civilization. See how principles of distance, ratio, and alignment can uncover structures invisible to the naked eye and decode the mathematical secrets of a vanished world.

S2_D1_F4_C0.heading: Welcome to the Yucatan Peninsula!
S2_D1_F4_C0.body: I'm Dr. Nathaniel Cruz, and I'm leading an expedition to uncover Maya cities hidden beneath this jungle canopy. With cutting-edge LiDAR technology, we can now see what traditional archaeology couldn't reveal. Join me and Riley Morgan, our LiDAR engineer, as we use coordinate geometry to discover how the Maya applied sophisticated mathematics to their architecture. Let's begin our journey to unveil the mathematical genius of this ancient civilization!

S3.S3_D1_F5_C1: For decades, archaeologists have been trying to understand the full extent of Maya civilization in this region. Traditional methods only let us see what's been excavated—just the tip of the iceberg.
S3.S3_D2_F6_C2: That's why we've brought the LiDAR system. Light Detection and Ranging can penetrate the canopy and give us a complete picture of what lies beneath.
S3.S3_D3_F7_C1: Let me show you how it works. Our drone emits millions of laser pulses that bounce off different surfaces. Some reflect from the canopy, some from branches, and crucially, some make it all the way to the ground.
S3.S3_D4_F8_C2: Since we know the drone's exact position and measure the time for each pulse to return, we can create precise 3D coordinates for each point the laser hits.
S3.S3_D5_F9_C1: Our <no-glossary>survey</no-glossary> area is this dense jungle, which likely contains undiscovered Maya structures that have been hidden for centuries.
S3.S3_D6_F10_C2: Would you like to see LiDAR in action? Let me set up the drone for a scan of this sector.

S4_D0_F11_C9.title: LiDAR Jungle Survey

about.heading: About LiDAR in Archaeology
about.body:
• LiDAR Technology:
    • • Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) uses laser pulses to map terrain
    • • Laser beams penetrate vegetation to reveal hidden structures
    • • Different colors represent where the laser beam is reflected
    • • This technology revolutionized Maya archaeology by revealing cities beneath dense jungle
  • Archaeological Context:
    • • Ancient Maya cities often remain hidden under centuries of jungle growth
    • • LiDAR helps archaeologists discover features like temples, roads and terraces
    • • The simulation shows how archaeologists use filtered LiDAR data to identify human-made structures
    • • Patterns in the data reveal rectangular buildings, pathways and city layouts

help.heading: How to use this tool
help.body:
• Navigation Controls:
    • • Mouse drag: Rotate camera around the scene
    • • Mouse wheel: Zoom in and out
    • • Left panel: View scan statistics and control scanning
  • Scanning Process:
    • • Click Start LiDAR Scan to begin surveying the area
    • • Green dots represent canopy (tree) hits
    • • Blue dots show ground surface hits
    • • Orange dots indicate potential structure hits
    • • Click Show Data Analysis to view the 2D map of discovered features
  • Tips:
    • • Look for patterns in the orange dots as structures are revealed
    • • Complete the full scan to reveal all hidden archaeological features
    • • The compass helps you maintain orientation during exploration

labels.instructions: Use mouse to rotate view, wheel to zoom

messages.ready: Ready to begin LiDAR scan of jungle terrain.
messages.complete: Scan complete! Ancient Maya city fully mapped and analyzed.
messages.paused: Scan Stopped. Press Start Scan to scan again.

S4_D0_F11_C9.graphDescription: A 3D interactive component simulating a jungle environment with a drone scanning for hidden pathways and ancient city structures. It includes features like a compass, scan progress, and filtered data visualization for canopy, ground, and structure hits.

S4.S4_D1_F11_C2: This interface shows us our real-time data collection. As we proceed, the green dots represent canopy hits, blue dots represent ground returns, and orange dots indicate potential structure points.
S4.S4_D2_F12_C1: Go ahead and start the scan when you're ready. Watch carefully as the data comes in.
S4.S4_D3_F13_C1: Great! The scan is now active. You can see how the laser pulses are already mapping the jungle canopy with those green points.
S4.S4_D4_F14_C2: For a more detailed view of what we're collecting, click the 'Show Data Analysis' button in the top right. This will help us see patterns as they emerge.
S4.S4_D5_F15_C2: Look at the analysis window! See those blue points forming a linear pattern? That's not natural—that looks like an ancient pathway running east to west.
S4.S4_D6_F16_C1: Exactly! The LiDAR is revealing what the jungle has been hiding. As we continue scanning, watch for more geometric patterns in both displays.
S4.S4_D7_F17_C2: The scan is now revealing something remarkable to the east—notice those orange points clustering in regular geometric shapes?
S4.S4_D8_F18_C1: Those are structure foundations! Based on the arrangement, we're looking at a ceremonial complex. See how they form precise right angles and aligned orientations?
S4.S4_D9_F19_C1: Scan complete! We've just mapped an entire Maya city that's been hidden for centuries.
S4.S4_D10_F20_C2: The data shows something like a ceremonial center surrounded by smaller structures and connected by a formal pathway.
S4.S4_D11_F21_C1: The Maya were sophisticated mathematicians and astronomers. They built their cities with precise geometric principles—perfect right angles, exact proportions, and alignments to celestial events.
S4.S4_D12_F22_C2: Now that we have this point cloud data, we can use coordinate geometry to analyze these structures and understand their significance.
S4.S4_D13_F23_C1: This is a major discovery. Are you ready to help us uncover the mathematical secrets of this lost Maya city?

S5_D0_F24_C9.title: LiDAR Survey Result

about.heading: About LiDar Data
about.body:
What you're seeing:
  • • Filtered LiDAR data with vegetation removed
  • • Bare earth model showing hidden structures
  • • Archaeological features revealed under jungle canopy
  • • Maya city layout with central pyramid, structures, and pathways

help.heading: How to read this map
help.body:
• • Green dots: Vegetation canopy
  • • Blue dots: Ground surface
  • • Bright blue dots: Ancient pathway
  • • Orange dots: Archaeological structures

S5_D0_F24_C9.graphDescription: Analysis results showing a jungle environment with hidden pathways and ancient city structures. It includes filtered data visualization for canopy, ground, and structure hits.

S5.S5_D1_F24_C1: The initial LiDAR scan results are coming in. We've identified what appears to be a perfectly straight pathway.
S5.S5_D2_F25_C2: It's too precise to be natural. This has to be a wall or ceremonial path built by the Maya.
S5.S5_D3_F26_C1: The endpoints are clearly major architectural features. It's precisely the kind of pattern we've been searching for.
S5.S5_D4_F27_C2: I'm logging the endpoints as points A - (x1, y1) and B - (x2, y2) in our coordinate system for further analysis.
S5.S5_D5_F28_C1: This matches patterns we've seen at other sites. Maya architects often positioned shrines or temples at specific ratio points along major pathways.
S5.S5_D6_F29_C2: Yes, they frequently used proportional ratios like 3:2 or 7:3 to determine where to place ritual structures.
S5.S5_D7_F30_C1: It's remarkable how they applied these mathematical principles without modern tools.
S5.S5_D8_F31_C2: That's where coordinate geometry becomes valuable for us. We can use the partition formula to calculate where a shrine might be located.
S5.S5_D9_F32_C1: The partition formula is perfect for this situation. If we have two points A and B, and want to find a point P that divides it in ratio a:b.
S5.S5_D10_F33_C2:
If a point divides segment AB in the ratio a:b, then the coordinates of the point are:
B X 1 plus A X 2 divided by A + B and B Y 1 plus A Y 2 divided by A + B(bx1 + ax2
a + b, by1 + ay2
a + b)
S5.S5_D11_F34_C2: Let's use this formula to analyze where we should focus our excavation efforts along this wall <no-glossary>segment</no-glossary>.

about.heading: About Maya Architectural Proportion
about.body:
Archaeological Context:

  • Ancient Maya architects used precise mathematical ratios in their structures
  • Key architectural features were often positioned using specific proportions
  • This tool simulates archaeological fieldwork using LiDAR and ground surveys
  • Imperial measurements (feet) are used following archaeological convention

Mathematical Concept:

  • Point P divides segment AB in ratio m
  • If ratio is a:b, then P is positioned at aa+b of the total length from A
  • Example: 3:2 ratio places P at 35 (60%) of the distance from A to B
  • This positioning was critical for astronomical alignments and ritual spaces

help.heading: How to use this tool
help.body:
Basics:

  • Drag points A and B change the foundation line length and angle
  • You can also enter coordinates for points A and B in the text box
  • Adjust the ratio using the input fields to position structure P
  • Toggle the structure to show/hide the Maya building
  • Reset returns to default settings

Tips:

  • Structure P divides segment AB according to the specified ratio
  • The coordinate grid shows measurements in feet
  • Distances are automatically calculated as you adjust points
  • Verify measurements in the bottom panel

translations.placementRatioDescription: Ratio {ratio1}:{ratio2} means structure P is positioned to divide foundation AB in ratio {ratio1} to {ratio2}
translations.formulaDescription: For points A(x₁, y₁), B(x₂, y₂), and ratio {ratio1}:{ratio2}
translations.resultDescription: Position of P : ({partitionX},{partitionY}), or {partitionRatioPercent}% of total length
translations.canvasDescription: Analytical system showing LiDAR data and coordinate geometry calculations. It includes features like point marking, distance calculations, and filtered data visualization for ground returns.

S6.S6_D1_F35_C2: I've uploaded the LiDAR data to our analytical system. We can now calculate where a Maya shrine might be positioned along this straight segment.
S6.S6_D2_F36_C1: Our endpoint coordinates are clearly defined. Point A is at (150, 200) and point B is at (450, 200).
S6.S6_D3_F37_C2: Maya architects commonly positioned important structures at points that divide pathways in a 3:2 ratio. Can you calculate where we should focus our excavation?
S6.S6_D4_F38_C2: That's right! The coordinates are (330, 200). Let me mark this spot on our map.
S6.S6_D5_F39_C1: Fascinating! The LiDAR data shows an anomaly almost exactly at that position. Your calculation matches what we're seeing in the point cloud.
S6.S6_D6_F40_C2: Different regions sometimes used different proportional systems. Let's test another common Maya ratio: 7:3.
S6.S6_D7_F41_C1: If we adjust to a 7:3 ratio, how far along the segment would the shrine be positioned, as a percentage from point A?
S6.S6_D8_F42_C1: Precisely! At a 7:3 ratio, the shrine would be positioned 70% of the way from point A to point B.
S6.S6_D9_F43_C2: This is consistent with what we've seen at other Late Classic <no-glossary>period</no-glossary> sites. The Maya were remarkably consistent with these proportions.
S6.S6_D10_F44_C1: This is exactly why mathematics is so powerful in archaeology. We're using the same geometric principles the Maya used, but to rediscover what they built.
S6.S6_D11_F45_C2: Now that we've identified these key points, let's examine what kind of structure might be at the first location we calculated.

S7.S7_D1_F46_C1: Now that we've identified this key point using the partition formula, I'm getting more detailed LiDAR readings of the area.
S7.S7_D2_F47_C2: The point cloud data is showing something very interesting around those coordinates.
S7.S7_D3_F48_C1: It appears to be a raised platform with clear geometric boundaries. This could be a ceremonial plaza.
S7.S7_D4_F49_C2: Maya ceremonial architecture typically followed precise geometric principles. They weren't just building at random.
S7.S7_D5_F50_C1: Absolutely. Their most important ritual spaces often adhered to specific proportions that reflected their cosmological beliefs.
S7.S7_D6_F51_C2: To determine if this is indeed a major ceremonial space, we need to measure its dimensions accurately.
S7.S7_D7_F52_C1: The distance formula will be essential here. For any two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), the distance between them is…
S7.S7_D8_F53_C2: √[(x₂ − x₁)² + (y₂ − y₁)²]. We'll need to apply this formula to each side of the structure.
S7.S7_D9_F54_C1: And once we have the dimensions, we can calculate both the perimeter and the area.
S7.S7_D10_F55_C2: Most importantly, we need to determine the ratio of length to width. The sacred 2:1 ratio is particularly significant in Maya architecture.
S7.S7_D11_F56_C1: That specific proportion appears frequently at major sites like Tikal and Chichen Itza. It's associated with primary ceremonial spaces.
S7.S7_D12_F57_C2: Yes but first, let's understand how to use the distance formula to verify the measurements.

about.heading: About Distance Formula
about.body:
Mathematical Foundation:

  • The distance formula is derived from the Pythagorean theorem
  • It calculates the straight-line distance between two points in a coordinate plane
  • Essential for navigation, engineering, and geometric calculations
  • Used in computer graphics, GPS systems, and architectural design

Key Concepts:

  • Two points A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂) create a right triangle
  • Horizontal distance: Δx = x₂ - x₁
  • Vertical distance: Δy = y₂ - y₁
  • Pythagorean theorem: d² = Δx² + Δy²
  • Final formula: d = √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]

help.heading: How to use Distance Formula
help.body:
Interactive Steps:

  • Click on the grid to place two points A and B
  • Toggle the triangle to show/hide the right triangle formed by the points
  • Watch the calculations as Δx and Δy are computed automatically
  • See the distance formula applied step by step using Pythagorean theorem
  • Reset to clear points and start over

What You'll Learn:

  • How coordinate differences create the sides of a right triangle
  • The connection between Pythagorean theorem and distance calculation
  • Why the distance formula works for any two points
  • Real-world applications of coordinate geometry

translations.differencesEquation:
Differences:
Δx = x2 - x1
Δy = y2 - y1
translations.pythagoreanTheoremEquation:
Pythagorean Theorem:
d2 = Δx2 + Δy2
d2 = (x2 - x1)2 + (y2 - y1)2
translations.distanceFormula:
Distance Formula:
d = √[(x2 - x1)2 + (y2 - y1)2]

S8I.S8I_D1_F59_C1: Riley, let's place two points on the coordinate grid: point A and point B.
S8I.S8I_D2_F60_C2: Alright, I see both points. What's the first step to find the distance between them?
S8I.S8I_D3_F61_C1: We draw a right triangle between the points. The horizontal side represents the change in x, and the vertical side represents the change in y.
S8I.S8I_D4_F62_C2: So the horizontal distance is Δx = x2 - x1, and the vertical distance is Δy = y2 - y1.
S8I.S8I_D5_F63_C1: Correct. Now we apply the Pythagorean theorem. The distance squared is d2 = Δx2 + Δy2.
S8I.S8I_D6_F64_C2: And taking the square root, the distance is d = √( (x2 - x1)2 + (y2 - y1)2 ).
S8I.S8I_D7_F65_C1: Perfect! That's the distance formula. It works for any two points on the coordinate plane.
S8I.S8I_D8_F66_C2: Now let's analyze this platform carefully using the distance formula.

about.heading: About Maya Architecture
about.body:
Archaeological Context:

  • Maya ceremonial platforms typically have precise 2:1 ratios
  • LiDAR data reveals geometric patterns beneath jungle growth
  • Archaeologists map structures before excavation
  • Analysis of dimensions helps identify structure function

help.heading: How to use this tool
help.body:
Basic Controls:

  • Click on the map to mark structure corners or use input boxes to add new points.
  • You can enter the coordinates through the text box
  • Click red X to remove points
  • Use Show Guide to see target outline
  • Click Reset to start over

Analysis Tips:

  • Look for rectangular patterns in the point cloud
  • Maya structures often have a 2:1 length-to-width ratio
  • Right angles are key architectural features
  • The tool will calculate measurements automatically

translations.dataLegend: LiDAR Ground Return Data - 9.8 ft above surface
translations.statusDescription1: Need {numPoints} more point(or points) to calculate measurements
translations.insightsDescription1: 2:1 ratio matches classic Maya ceremonial platforms
translations.insightsDescription2: Right angles demonstrate Maya engineering precision
translations.objetiveDescription: Mark 4 points around the Maya structure visible in the LiDAR data. Look for rectangular patterns with right angles and a 2:1 ratio - common features in Maya ceremonial architecture.
translations.successDescription: You've successfully identified a Maya ceremonial platform with the classic 2:1 ratio and perfect right angles! This structure likely served an important ritual purpose in ancient Maya society.
translations.nextStepDescription: Continue your exploration to find ancient pathways connecting this structure to other Maya sites.
translations.canvasDescription: 2D component simulating a LiDAR analysis of a Maya structure. It includes features like point marking, distance calculations, and filtered data visualization for ground returns.

S8.S8_D1_F58_C2: I've loaded the LiDAR data into our analysis system. We can now mark each corner of the structure to calculate its measurements in imperial units.
S8.S8_D2_F59_C1: The filtered data clearly shows a rectangular platform. Notice the brighter cyan points at what appear to be the corners of the structure.
S8.S8_D3_F60_C2: Using the coordinates of the four corners of the platform [(-67,50), (-67,-50), (133,50), (133,-50)], we need to calculate its perimeter in feet.
S8.S8_D4_F61_C2: Let's calculate the perimeter of the Maya platform with the given coordinates.
S8.S8_D5_F62_C1: Excellent! A perimeter of 600 feet. It reveals Maya mathematical precision. Their perfectly rectangular structures weren't accidental–it was mathematical knowledge put into practice.
S8.S8_D6_F63_C2: Using the same coordinates, can you now tell what is the area of this platform?
S8.S8_D7_F64_C1: Perfect! 20,000 square feet. That's approximately the size of four modern football fields combined!
S8.S8_D8_F65_C2: Now for the critical analysis - what is the length-to-width ratio of this platform, and what might this tell us about its ceremonial purpose?
S8.S8_D9_F66_C2: What is the length-to-width ratio and what does it indicate about the platform's purpose?
S8.S8_D10_F67_C1: That's right! The 2:1 ratio is a hallmark of Maya ceremonial architecture. At approximately 200 ft by 100 ft, this structure follows the sacred proportions found at major ceremonial centers like Tikal and Palenque across the Maya world.
S8.S8_D11_F68_C2: This mathematical signature confirms our archaeological <no-glossary>hypothesis</no-glossary>. The structure's specific proportions indicate this was a primary ritual space rather than a secondary or residential structure.
S8.S8_D12_F69_C1: Magnificent! You've identified a Maya ceremonial platform with the sacred 2:1 ratio. This platform would have been the site of important public ceremonies and ritual performances that were central to Maya society.
S8.S8_D13_F70_C2: By carefully measuring and analyzing the coordinates, you've revealed not just the physical dimensions but the cultural significance of this structure. This mathematical approach allows us to understand Maya architecture without disturbing the site.

S9.S9_D1_F71_C1: Our discoveries so far have been remarkable. The ceremonial plaza and shrine positions suggest this was a major Maya center.
S9.S9_D2_F72_C2: I've just finished processing the complete LiDAR dataset for the entire 2 square kilometer area surrounding our initial findings.
S9.S9_D3_F73_C1: Excellent! Now we can <no-glossary>expand</no-glossary> our analysis to understand the full extent of this settlement.
S9.S9_D4_F74_C2: The complete dataset contains millions of data points from different elevation levels. We'll need to filter through them systematically.
S9.S9_D5_F75_C1: The challenge is separating the vegetation returns from the actual architectural features.
S9.S9_D6_F76_C2: That's where our filtering tools come in. We can <no-glossary>isolate</no-glossary> the layer and see what's hidden.
S9.S9_D7_F77_C1: And with our coordinate geometry techniques, we can analyze how all these structures relate to each other.
S9.S9_D8_F78_C2: Maya cities weren't randomly organized. Their layout often reflected cosmological principles and political hierarchies.
S9.S9_D9_F79_C1: Precisely. By examining alignments, proportions, and spatial relationships, we can understand how the entire settlement functioned.
S9.S9_D10_F80_C2: Our toolkit includes everything we've used so far—the partition formula, distance calculations, and area measurements—plus additional analytical tools.
S9.S9_D11_F81_C1: It's time to put all these mathematical techniques together to unlock the full story of this lost Maya city.

about.heading: About Ancient Maya Cities
about.body:
City Layout Features:

  • Triangle Garden: Ceremonial triangular space
  • Rectangle Plaza: Central gathering area
  • Circle Reservoir: Water collection basin
  • Sacbe: Raised limestone pathways connecting important areas
  • Defensive walls with gates protected the city center

help.heading: How to use this tool
help.body:
Filtering Mode:

  • Toggle vegetation layer to reveal hidden structures
  • Use left-click + drag to rotate the camera view
  • Use mouse wheel to zoom in and out
  • Use right-click + drag to pan the view

Measurement Mode:

  • Select a structure to analyze from the feature list
  • Measurements update automatically when we select the structure

translations.canvasDescription: 3D component simulating a LiDAR analysis of a Maya city. It includes features like point marking, distance calculations, and filtered data visualization for ground returns.

step1.description: Turn off vegetation layer to proceed

step2.description: Select a feature below to measure
step2.measurementDescription: Select a feature to begin measuring
step2.triangleMeasureMethod: AB ≈ 27 ft, BC ≈ 30 ft, AC ≈ 27 ft, Triangle area calculated using Heron's formula: √(s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)) where s is half the perimeter
step2.rectangleMeasureMethod: AB = 50 ft, BC = 50 ft, AC = 50 ft, AD = 50 ft, Rectangle area calculated as width × height
step2.circleMeasureMethod: Radius is 10 ft, Circle area calculated using π × r²
step2.polygonMeasureMethod: Polygon area calculated using the Shoelace formula
step2.defaultMeasureMethod: Area calculated using the Shoelace formula for irregular polygons

S10.S10_D1_F82_C2: Welcome to the Ancient City Explorer. I've loaded all the filtering and analysis tools for our use.
S10.S10_D2_F83_C1: Let's start by toggling off the vegetation layer to see what lies beneath the jungle cover.
S10.S10_D3_F84_C2: Look at that! As we filter out the vegetation layer, numerous structures are becoming visible across the landscape.
S10.S10_D4_F85_C1: I'm noticing several linear features radiating outward from the main plaza. They appear elevated above the surrounding terrain.
S10.S10_D5_F86_C2: Based on their elevated profile and straight alignment, what Maya architectural features do these likely represent?
S10.S10_D6_F87_C1: These raised, straight structures connected different areas of Maya cities. These are sacbeob—raised limestone causeways that connected important parts of Maya cities.
S10.S10_D7_F88_C2: These engineered roads weren't just practical—providing dry passage during rainy seasons—they had important ceremonial functions and likely reflected political relationships between different architectural groups.
S10.S10_D8_F89_C1: Let's proceed to the measurement step to analyze these features more precisely.
S10.S10_D9_F90_C2: In this step, we can select specific structures and measure their dimensions. Let's start with the Rectangle Plaza at the center.
S10.S10_D10_F91_C1: The plaza spans exactly 50 feet by 50 feet with an area of 2500 square feet.
S10.S10_D11_F92_C2: Each side measures 50 feet—that’s interesting. But we shouldn’t jump to conclusions about its classification just from those numbers.
S10.S10_D11_F92X_C1: Exactly. On a <no-glossary>coordinate plane</no-glossary>, you could verify this by using the <no-glossary>distance formula</no-glossary> to check all four side lengths. If they’re all equal, that shows it’s at least a <no-glossary>rhombus</no-glossary>.
S10.S10_D11_F92Y_C2: And then you’d use the slopes of consecutive sides to check if they’re perpendicular. If they are, then it’s also a <no-glossary>rectangle</no-glossary>.
S10.S10_D11_F92Z_C1: Correct. A shape that’s both a <no-glossary>rectangle</no-glossary> and a <no-glossary>rhombus</no-glossary>. What would we call it?
S10.S10_D11_F92XW_C2: That’s correct—it’s a square. Nice work reasoning it through step by step!
S10.S10_D12_F93_C2: This precision suggests standardized measurement units in Maya architecture. Now let’s try measuring the <no-glossary>Triangle</no-glossary> Garden.
S10.S10_D12_FX_C1: It measures about 27 feet on two sides and 30 feet on the base.
S10.S10_D13_F94_C2: If we were working on a <no-glossary>coordinate plane</no-glossary>, we could determine those side lengths using the distance <no-glossary>formula</no-glossary>. That would let us classify the triangle by its sides—scalene, isosceles, or equilateral—and also by its angles as acute, right, or obtuse.
S10.S10_D14_F95_C1: In this case, with two equal sides and no right angle. So, here’s your question:
S10.S10_D14_F95X_C2: The Triangle Garden has two equal sides. What type of triangle is this?
S10.S10_D14_F95Y_C1: The Triangle Garden forms an isosceles triangle and connects directly to one of the main sacbeob. It's remarkable how precisely these structures were positioned.
S10.S10_D14_F95_C2: Now let's examine the Circle Reservoir.
S10.S10_D15_F96_C1: The reservoir has a diameter of exactly 20 feet. When we analyze all these structures together, I'm seeing a pattern emerging in their arrangement.
S10.S10_D16_F97_C2: Indeed! The different geometric forms—<no-glossary>triangle</no-glossary>, <no-glossary>rectangle</no-glossary>, circle—together with their connecting sacbeob, appear to represent different cosmic domains in Maya cosmology.
S10.S10_D17_F98_C1: This comprehensive analysis has transformed our understanding of this site. What began as hidden structures has revealed a city organized according to sophisticated mathematical and cosmological principles.
S10.S10_D18_F99_C2: And we've accomplished this using digital tools without excavation—demonstrating the power of combining 3D visualization with archaeological analysis.

S11.S11_D1_F102_C1: Back at our base camp, I'm still amazed by what we've discovered through mathematical analysis alone.
S11.S11_D2_F103_C2: It's remarkable how coordinate geometry has revealed an entire Maya city that's been hidden for centuries.
S11.S11_D3_F104_C1: We started with just a few anomalies in the LiDAR data, but by applying the partition formula, we located ritual structures positioned at precise proportional points.
S11.S11_D4_F105_C2: The comprehensive analysis using our full toolkit revealed even more: the network of sacbeob connecting different parts of the site, standardized measurement units in residential areas, and the three-part cosmological division embedded in building designs.
S11.S11_D5_F106_C1: This expedition has demonstrated how powerful coordinate geometry can be for archaeological discovery. The partition formula, distance calculations, and proportional analysis have unlocked secrets that have been hidden for over a thousand years.
S11.S11_D6_F107_C2: And this is just the beginning. With these mathematical tools, we can continue to explore and understand not just where the Maya built, but how and why they designed their cities the way they did.
S11.S11_D7_F108_C1: I can't think of a more powerful demonstration of how mathematics connects to our understanding of human history and culture.

quest_completion.subheading: You've uncovered the mathematical genius of Maya civilization!
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the LiDAR & Lines: Uncovering Maya Mathematics STEAMQuest.

  • You applied the partition formula to locate hidden ceremonial structures
  • You used distance and area calculations to verify Maya design principles
  • You discovered the sacred 2:1 ratio and cosmological patterns in Maya architecture
  • You revealed how coordinate geometry can uncover secrets hidden for centuries

The mathematical principles you practiced continue to unlock archaeological discoveries today!
quest_completion.leftsvgarialabel: Paint brush and palette knife art tools.

lidar.definition: LiDAR is Light Detection and Ranging; a technology that uses laser pulses to create detailed 3D maps of landscapes and structures hidden beneath vegetation.

canopy.definition: Canopy is the uppermost layer of a forest formed by tree crowns, which LiDAR technology can penetrate to reveal what lies beneath.

sacbeob.definition: Sacbeob are raised limestone causeways built by the Maya to connect important parts of their cities, providing dry passage and serving ceremonial functions.

sacbe.definition: Sacbe is a raised limestone causeway built by the Maya to connect important parts of their cities, providing dry passage and serving ceremonial functions.

cosmological_principles.definition: Cosmological principles are ideas about the structure of the universe that the Maya incorporated into their architecture, such as the three-part division representing different worlds.

point_cloud.definition: Point cloud is a set of data points collected by LiDAR that represents the external surfaces of terrain and structures in three-dimensional space.

anomaly.definition: Anomaly is an unusual feature in LiDAR data that differs from natural patterns, potentially indicating human-made structures.

common.cruz_description: Middle-aged male with glasses and salt-and-pepper beard, wearing beige button-up shirt and smart watch, holding a tablet.
common.riley_description: Young female with wavy brown hair, wearing navy vest over beige shirt, patterned scarf, and wristwatch, holding a folder.
common.bg1_description: Ancient Mayan pyramid emerging through jungle mist, stone steps rising toward the sky, surrounded by lush tropical forest with tall trees filtering golden sunlight, as a lone explorer gazes at the mystical scene.
common.bg2_description: Rainforest research expedition with canvas tents and monitoring equipment, researchers operating a drone amid tropical foliage, golden sunlight filtering through the dense canopy, creating a green-tinted atmospheric scene.
common.bg3_description: Open-air jungle research station with wooden roof structure, scientists analyzing environmental data on large digital displays, panoramic views of lush tropical vegetation and blue sky, warm sunset light illuminating the workspace.
common.bg4_description: Jungle research tent with wooden platform and transparent walls, scientist studying maps and data at drafting table, panoramic view of misty rainforest mountains, warm wood interior contrasting with cool blue-tinted exterior landscape.
common.bg5_description: Archaeological expedition at a jungle clearing with researchers surveying ancient stone ruins, one team member analyzing data on laptop, golden sunset light illuminating the site against a backdrop of lush rainforest and distant mountains.
common.bg6_description: Nighttime research camp in tropical forest with illuminated A-frame tents, scientists gathered around campfire under starry sky, distant mountain ranges silhouetted against twilight horizon, warm golden lights contrasting with cool blue nightfall.
